The flâneur’s path appears random but is guided by curiosity and attraction. This describes a middle path between structured exploration and pure chance—a mindful wandering that follows intuitive pulls while maintaining awareness.

item.title: breakneck dan wang
item.description: guizhao - datacenter center of china railroad system from shanghai <> beijing started at same time as sf <> la in 2008 finished in 2011, while la is still not until 2030 lawyer vs engineering state fengzhou - alibaba shanghai well-connected hangzhou - alibaba suzhou - manufacturing wetland parks around bike path economic growth rate 10% a year americans dont like infra projects rare environmental impact save for texas/arizona default in coastal cities is towards rigidity little eagerness for physical change manufacturing in china lot of influence from soviet union / manufacturing production vs consumption china is lightly taxxed on property taxes - moreso consumption tax welfare 10% on social spending compared to higher # s in US and europe esp on unemployment worrying that welfare cna make ppl lazy feels like chinese parents lmao central planning has resonance with china’s engineering state / construction and control leaders deng xiao ping huge differential in life outcomes for someone born in 1949 vs 1959 tik tok trends and cultural trends how fast is it?

item.title: goodreads redesign
item.description: problems: as an avid reader disconnected from my friends its hard for me to maintain digital book clubs scheduling issues remembering the book we discussed as a poetry lover its hard for me to find fellow poetry lovers online im reading too many books at once difficult to discuss think pieces together finding ppl interested -> sending them article -> reading it / dissecting it together ideas: feature to sync up reading amongst devices accountability tracker (nudge ppl to read) find other ppl reading same book as u to chat creating a book club with other people recommending books based on someone’s book tastes discovery for new books

item.title: gpu orchestration masterbook - winter 25
item.description: Learning Plan Phase 0 - [[GPUs Fundamentals]] Topics GPU Components: SMs, HBM, interconnects Thermal vs power vs memory failures ECC errors (correctable vs uncorrectable) Why IB / NVLink issues masquerade as “GPU failures” -> what does healthy GPU really mean?

item.title: GPUs Fundamentals
item.description: What are the errors you can see Storage Primer Issues come in four ways: Persistent storage object storage (S3 / Blob) / network file systems (NFS / Lustre / GPFS ) / bloc storage (PD, EBS, local SSD) / node-local NVMe Data ingestion Check point downloads / datasets shards / containers images / model weights Runtime i / o mmap / read() / page cache / PCIe DMA / GPU memory copies GPU execution HBM / SRAM / Compute SRAM is the tiny whiteboard next to the compute - used for L1/L2 Caches no refresh however it has huge area cost on the chip HBM isued for model weights , kv cache, insane bandwidth its a big storage next to gpu many GPU utilization problems are actually memory hierarchy problems GPUs are uniquely sensitive to storage - CPUs tolerate slowness bc “CPU threads block / OS scheduler hides latency - you get slow, but it still works”.

item.title: hawaii trip post-mortem
item.description: i am extremely frustrated with how mich/esther handled this situation in terms of agreeing to go on this trip becoming wishy washy once it came to details and time to commit i booked ticket as forcing fucntion for ppl to commit instead ppl saw it as a constraint and decided to prioritize things over it michelle wouldnt give us a clear answer of whether or not she could go said she felt really bad about flaking but also felt bad about skipping out on the concert eventually gave us the reason that she doesnt know what to do in oahu and it was too expensive and she would be stressed which is so stupid bc oahu is the first place anyone goes to and also she’s going to a trip to taiwan so this logic doesnt make any sense esther also wouldnt give clear answer on whether she wanted to go said she would only go to maui any relationship requires you to commit true friendship requires you to commit it is not enough to be endlessly open -> you need to convert intent into action if you needlessly choose any friend over this group its a clear indication the group is not stable why do i struggle so hard to maintain these female friendships?

item.title: how to be bored
item.description: thesis: in stillness you train your ability to observe analysis - as someone who seeks novelty - nature is a necessary shock to my system - i often wonder how poets come from the most boring of places in middle america - to writing glorious pieces about the everyday - like ada limon and the plume of birds - mary oliver - industrious hummingbirds, egrets, motionless ponds, “lean owls / hunkering with their lamp-eyes - “stands quite comfortably on the margins of things, on the line between earth and sky, the thin membrane that separates human from what we loosely call animal.

item.title: notes from inside the datacenter
item.description: Modern data-center construction began in the nineties, with the arrival of the commercial internet. Data centers hosted websites, coördinated e-mail, processed payments, and streamed video and music.

item.title: NVL
item.description: the problen NV had to solve: PCIE is too slow for GPU <> GPU traffic at scale multi-GPU workloads need high bandwidth low latency solution: build dedicated GPU-only interconnect point2point, packetized, cache-coherent link allows GPU A to read/write memory on GPU B without going thru CPU memory NVSwitch

item.title: signal detection theory
item.description: https://www.keiseruniversity.edu/signal-detection-theory/ At its core, signal detection theory involves the measurement of the difference between two distinct patterns. The first is called the “stimulus” when you’re talking about some type of living organism or the “signal” when you’re talking about a machine.

item.title: The housing theory of everything

item.title: unused urban spaces
item.description: unused urban spaces #urbanism some plazas attract a lot of ppl in nyc — most dont some are only used for walking across most ppl who use plazas are young office workers from nearby plazas change way of life best used plazas are sociable places higher than average proportion of women in most used place women going is good signal ppl gravitate towards lots of ppl ppl dont rlly choose to stand in the middle of a large place preference for pillars movement thru space patterns not specific to nyc — based on other societies jan gehl’s study of self-congestion — mapped patterns similar here “Contrary to ‘common sense’ expectations,” Ciolek notes, “the great majority of people were found to select their sites for social interaction right on or very close to the traffic lines intersecting the plaza.
